findings:
- Cardiomegaly with a cardiothoracic ratio exceeding 50%, suggesting an enlarged heart.
- Prominent pulmonary vasculature with increased vascular markings bilaterally, particularly in the upper lobes.
- Evidence of bilateral pleural effusion with fluid levels visible in the costophrenic angles and extending into the lower lung fields.
- Blunting of the costophrenic angles bilaterally, consistent with fluid accumulation.
- No visible lung consolidation or lobar collapse.
- No significant mediastinal shift or deviation.
- No obvious fractures or bony abnormalities in the thoracic cage.
- No visible pneumothorax or subcutaneous emphysema.
- Diaphragm appears elevated on the right side, possibly due to volume loss or diaphragmatic paralysis.
impression:
- Congestive heart failure with pulmonary edema and bilateral pleural effusions.
- Possible chronic pulmonary hypertension contributing to pulmonary vascular congestion.
- Right diaphragmatic elevation may suggest diaphragmatic dysfunction or volume loss secondary to chronic lung disease or effusion.
- No acute pulmonary infection or pneumothorax identified.
full_response:
Findings: - Cardiomegaly with a cardiothoracic ratio exceeding 50%, suggesting an enlarged heart.
- Prominent pulmonary vasculature with increased vascular markings bilaterally, particularly in the upper lobes.
- Evidence of bilateral pleural effusion with fluid levels visible in the costophrenic angles and extending into the lower lung fields.
- Blunting of the costophrenic angles bilaterally, consistent with fluid accumulation.
- No visible lung consolidation or lobar collapse.
- No significant mediastinal shift or deviation.
- No obvious fractures or bony abnormalities in the thoracic cage.
- No visible pneumothorax or subcutaneous emphysema.
- Diaphragm appears elevated on the right side, possibly due to volume loss or diaphragmatic paralysis.
Impression: - Congestive heart failure with pulmonary edema and bilateral pleural effusions.
- Possible chronic pulmonary hypertension contributing to pulmonary vascular congestion.
- Right diaphragmatic elevation may suggest diaphragmatic dysfunction or volume loss secondary to chronic lung disease or effusion.
- No acute pulmonary infection or pneumothorax identified.
